docs.title: vector_pro
docs.text: template < typename T > class vector_pro; // generic template

docs.title: Vector_pro
docs.text:
Same as std::vector, vector_pros are sequence containers representing arrays that can change in size.

Vector_pros use contiguous storage locations for their elements. Unlike arrays, their size can change dynamically, with their storage being handled automatically by the container.

Don't have much differences with vectors, vector_pros use a dynamically allocated array to store their elements. Instead of reallocating each time an element is added to the container, vector_pro containers may allocate some extra storage to accommodate for possible growth, and thus the container may have an actual capacity greater than the storage strictly needed to contain its elements (i.e., its size). However we currently not support libraries to implement different strategies for growth to balance between memory usage and reallocations, we just simply double the capacity at logarithmically growing intervals of size so that the insertion of individual elements at the end of the vector can be provided with amortized constant time complexity (see push_back).

docs.title: Template parameters
docs.text:
template <typename T>

Only if T is guaranteed to not throw while moving, implementations can optimize to move elements instead of copying them during reallocations.

docs.text: member type definition notes iterator_pro a random access iterator to value_type convertible to const_iterator const_iterator_pro a random access iterator to const value_type size_type an unsigned integral type usually the same as int64_t
